captions.text: Is it possible to create something out of nothing?
Or, more precisely, can energy be made into matter?
Yes, but only when it comes together
with its twin, antimatter.
And there's something pretty mysterious about antimatter:
there's way less of it out there than there should be.
Let's start with the most famous physics formula ever:
E equals m c squared.
It basically says that mass is concentrated energy,
and mass and energy are exchangeable,
like two currencies with a huge exchange rate.
90 trillion Joules of energy
are equivalent to 1 gram of mass.
But how do I actually transform energy into matter?
The magic word is <i>energy density</i>.
If you concentrate a huge amount
of energy in a tiny space,
new particles will come into existence.
If we look closer,
we see that these particles always come in pairs,
like twins.
That's because particles always have a counterpart,
an antiparticle,
and these are always produced
in exactly equal amounts: 50/50.
This might sound like science fiction,
but it's the daily life of particle accelerators.
In the collisions between two protons
at CERN's Large Hadron Collider,
billions of particles and antiparticles
are produced every second.
Consider, for example, the electron.
It has a very small mass and negative electric charge.
It's antiparticle, the positron,
has exactly the same mass,
but a positive electric charge.
But, apart from the opposite charges,
both particles are identical and perfectly stable.
And the same is true for their heavy cousins,
the proton and the antiproton.
Therefore, scientists are convinced
that a world made of antimatter
would look, feel, and smell just like our world.
In this antiworld,
we may find antiwater,
antigold,
and, for example,
an antimarble.
Now imagine that a marble and an antimarble
are brought together.
These two apparently solid objects
would completely disappear
into a big flash of energy,
equivalent to an atomic bomb.
Because combining matter and antimatter
would create so much energy,
science fiction is full of ideas
about harnessing the energy stored in antimatter,
for example, to fuel spaceships like Star Trek.
After all, the energy content of antimatter
is a billion times higher than conventional fuel.
The energy of one gram of antimatter would be enough
for driving a car 1,000 times around the Earth,
or to bring the space shuttle into orbit.
So why don't we use antimatter for energy production?
Well, antimatter isn't just sitting around,
ready for us to harvest.
We have to make antimatter
before we can combust antimatter,
and it takes a billion times more energy
to make antimatter
than you get back.
But, what if there was some antimatter in outer space
and we could dig it out one day
from an antiplanet somewhere.
A few decades ago, many scientists believed
that this could actually be possible.
Today, observations have shown
that there is no significant amount of antimatter
anywhere in the visible universe,
which is weird because, like we said before,
there should be just as much antimatter
as there is matter in the universe.
Since antiparticles and particles
should exist in equal numbers,
this missing antimatter?
Now that is a real mystery.
To understand what might be happening,
we must go back to the Big Bang.
In the instant the universe was created,
a huge amount of energy was transformed into mass,
and our initial universe contained
equal amounts of matter and antimatter.
But just a second later,
most matter and all of the antimatter
had destroyed one another,
producing an enormous amount of radiation
that can still be observed today.
Just about 100 millionths
of the original amount of matter stuck around
and no antimatter whatsoever.
"Now, wait!" you might say,
"Why did all the antimatter disappear
and only matter was left?"
It seems that we were somehow lucky
that a tiny asymmetry exists
between matter and antimatter.
Otherwise, there would be no particles at all
anywhere in the universe
and also no human beings.
But what causes this asymmetry?
Experiments at CERN are trying to find out the reason
why something exists
and why we don't live in a universe
filled with radiation only?
But, so far, we just don't know the answer.

title: What happened to antimatter? - Rolf Landua

comments.text:
An excellent presentation.   Clear and beautifully illustrated.   Something

comments.author: TheHeldriver

comments.text:
+Skarmx2 You are assuming there is a "normal" matter.

There were two types of matter, one received the name 'matter', the other 
received the name 'anti-matter' - that's it. We discovered what we know as 
just 'matter' before so 'anti-matter' receives its name in order to make it 
easy to understand that it's an opposite type of matter to the one we 
already knew.

Same with electric charges, one is called 'positive' and the other 
'negative' to properly illustrate how they work. Don't see what's so hard 
to understand about that.

comments.author: Poke Playah

comments.text:
+Poke Playah As far as I know, the Electromagnetic spectrum would depend on 
the wavelengths and energy in a photon. Photons are particles without mass 
or charge, and are thus their own "anti-particle", and have no 
anti-particle.A positron moving into a lower energy state (emitting light) 
would still return the sort of photon we are familiar with.


On that note, how do we know some of the more distant galaxies aren't 
completely made of anti-matter?
comments.author: 109Rage

comments.text:
+Poke Playah Well, that hypothetical matter that interacts with "anti em" 
is basically what the theory behind dark matter is. We know--or at least, 
hypothesize--that it exists, because it still has mass, and therefore 
interacts with other massive objects, like regular, detectable matter, via 
gravity. Antimatter also has mass, and can be detected based on 
gravitation, but it happens to interact with conventional electromagnetic 
radiation as well, including light. But I suppose it is also theoretically 
possible that there is some other "anti" aspect to conventional matter and 
energy, which is really what I was proposing in the first place--that 
energy and anti-energy separated at the big bang, which was caused by 
whatever caused it to occur in the first place.

And yes, all theories are "just theories," but having unsubstantiated 
theories is not at all a bad place to be in, as long as you aren't 
satisfied with them as truth enough--theories must be subject to scrutiny. 
At the current moment, my idea is not supported by any evidence, so I'm not 
even claiming it as truth, only as one possible way to approach the 
question posed about the prevalence of matter.
comments.author: Fieldstuck

comments.text:
+Fieldstuck You could also say that anti-matter means anti electrons and 
anti-electromagnetic spectrum which could have "anti" wavelengths we or our 
equipment couldn't perceive. All reasonable theories are still theories 
though.
comments.author: Poke Playah

comments.text:
+Poke Playah That's exactly the question physicists are trying to figure 
out--how could an asymmetry have emerged in the first place? Personally, I 
don't believe there was an asymmetry at the beginning. I think that there 
was a asymmetric distribution of matter and antimatter throughout the 
universe, and the majority of the antimatter is simply somewhere beyond our 
view. If the beginning of the big bang was actually an split of the basal 
energy into that energy which would evolve into matter and that would would 
evolve into antimatter, they would naturally have propelled their material 
descendants in opposite directions, meaning most of the matter collided 
with antimatter (in the space between the split energy forms), but a small 
amount of each went in equal and opposite directions.

comments.text:
I have been thinking something along the same lines. I refer to it as the 
universe and anti universe. In ours we have more matter, black holes, the 
photon and light energy, and an expanding universe. In the anti-universe 
there is more anti-matter, white holes, the anti-photon and dark energy, 
and a deflating or collapsing universe. I picture the system as dual 
vortexes spinning in opposite directions. The anti-universe has a negative 
spin. ->=<+ The universe has a positive spin. I do not think anti-matter is 
moving away from us. I think it is moving toward the opposite end of the 
Big Bang and being transformed into matter by the intense forces found at 
the singularity. When our universe reaches max expansion and the Big Freeze 
our universe will transfer into the role of the anti universe and begin 
deflating with a reverse spin as our anti universe then very small will 
experience what we call the big bang and transition into an expanding 
universe with a positive spin. I call this concept Dual Vortex Theory. I 
wouldn't know how to test or prove it or illustrate it with physics or math 
though.﻿
comments.author: Randy Sullivan Seck

comments.text:
In fact we do know something about why there are matters left instead of 
nothing but photons.

If you go through the cosmology classes you would know that the symmetry 
between matter and antimatter or so called CP symmetry only hold in thermal 
equilibrium.

As the space is expanding for our universe, it has an arrow of time. So the 
T symmetry doesn't work here. As the CPT symmetry is always right (this is 
a mathematical fact that you'd better believe), we know that the CP 
symmetry is also broken. which means:

1. The matter and antimatter doesn't conserve an exact symmetry during the 
big bang.

Also, the standard model and all the other models do allow:

2. matter and antimatter can converts to photons by themselves.

It is true that photons produce exactly half matter and half antimatter but 
the rate they turn back to photons is slightly different. That is how our 
story begins.﻿

in size. Would that not mean that the big bang had no beginning?
I'd like to think of it as like a logarithmic function of sort. As gravity 
reaches infinity going back in time, so does time. It never reaches its 
asymptotes. Which could give meaning to the heat death of the universe too.
But in those terms... wouldn't it mirror if you were to cross the 
asymptotes?
But then, if it is a mirror, and you add both sides of the graph 
together... you get 0. Conforming to the first law of thermodynamics?
Could that be the divide between matter and antimatter?
Could that be the reason for the expansion of the universe getting faster?﻿

comments.text:
I do not know how to test this or express it in math or physics other than 
taking all known equations and making them negative. Such as -E=(-m)(-c^2). 
While these do not make much sense or hold true in our universe they would 
in the anti-universe. The universe and anti-universe can be expressed as a 
reciprocal function such as y=x^-1 on a coordinate plane. In the positive 
positive quadrant you have the black hole at the top expressing infinity 
and near 0, and the photon to the far right expressing the speed of light 
and near 0. In the negative negative Quadrant you have the White Hold at 
the very bottom expressing negative infinity and near 0. To the very far 
left you have the anti-photon expressing the anti-speed of light.  Also, if 
the expansion of our universe is getting faster, this means the collapsing 
of the anti universe is also getting faster.

comments.text:
I always liked to imagine that the big bang actually created two universes 
of expanding space expanding in opposite directions. One filled with matter 
and the other filled with anti-matter.
 example:
>|<
[>] is matter
[<] is anti-matter
[ | ] is the singularity plane of the big bang where both matter and 
anti-matter are moving apart.
So that there is a equal amount of matter and anti matter, and not just a 
hypothesis that there is a asymmetry in matter creation. This theory is 
also compatible with the evidence that space is expanding and galaxies are 
moving away from us, but I'm not a scientist.﻿

comments.text:
I have been thinking something along the same lines. I refer to it as the 
universe and anti universe. In ours we have more matter, black holes, the 
photon and light energy, and an expanding universe. In the anti-universe 
there is more anti-matter, white holes, the anti-photon and dark energy, 
and a deflating or collapsing universe. I picture the system as dual 
vortexes spinning in opposite directions. The anti-universe has a negative 
spin. ->=<+ The universe has a positive spin. I do not think anti-matter is 
moving away from us. I think it is moving toward the opposite end of the 
Big Bang and being transformed into matter by the intense forces found at 
the singularity. When our universe reaches max expansion and the Big Freeze 
our universe will transfer into the role of the anti universe and begin 
deflating with a reverse spin as our anti universe then very small will 
experience what we call the big bang and transition into an expanding 
universe with a positive spin. I call this concept Dual Vortex Theory. I 
wouldn't know how to test or prove it or illustrate it with physics or math 
though.

+Fynx Factora First of all, since we're talking science, I'm talking about 
the scientific definition of a theory, not the google definition. Plus, the 
universe doesn't have an "edge" because that would mean there's space on 
the other side of that edge, thereby meaning it is a part of the universe 
(as space, time, and other dimensions do not exist outside of the 
universe), thereby nullifying its being an edge. Logical proof right there. 
Also, those theories you listed, like I said about theories, have been 
tested up the ass and supported to the point that we can pretty much assume 
that they're true.

comments.text:
I know the answer. The antimatter is "in" the Proton. Did you get that? 
Electron and Positron pairs are (were) created in equal numbers inside of 
Quasars. Energy was added to the Positrons and they were converted into 
Protons. Then Protons and Electrons were expelled from the Quasars' North 
and South magnetic poles as "jets". This became Hydrogen and Stars and 
Galaxies. Whenever Proton/Antiproton pairs were created (or bigger particle 
pairs), they would just come back together and annihilate and the energy 
would be "recycled". Why would energy be added to the Positrons only, and 
not the Electrons? If by chance more Positrons were converted to Protons 
(then were Electrons converted to Antiprotons), then the Quasar would 
quickly become a stable matter producing object, because once you have more 
Protons than Antiprotons then any Antiprotons created would be quickly 
annihilated, while any Protons created would survive longer, and would 
become stably dominant.﻿

comments.text:
How do we know that there isn't a ton of anti-matter beyond the observable 
universe elsewhere in the universe?  Also, why do we assume just because 
experiments render seemingly symmetrical matter and anti-matter that all 
matter creation events must follow this rule?﻿
comments.author: Tletna

comments.text:
+Tletna  Thank you, too ;) Yep, that is very true and the same concerns 
have been raised in the scientific community in the past.

However there are still some points in favor of an argumentation like that:
There is always Ockheim's razor. That means a simple explantion is always 
favorable to a more complicated one. That is a very deep principle in 
logic. Let's imagine you had some data from an experiment that can be 
explained equally well by one model with only a few parameters and one with 
a large amount of parameters. Choosing the the model with the additional 
parameters could means that you actually choose a model that is either 
unnecessarily complicated or, even worse, one that does not reflect the 
processes rather well, but compensates by having additional parameters to 
correct for that defect. And asking for different physics beyond the 
visible universe to explain something that may be very well explainable 
though the physics we use in here is always disfavoured unless experimental 
evidence clearly shows the simpler model is incorrect. It sounds very 
complicated, but this is the principle that distinguishes ideas like an 
elliptical orbit of the moon around the earth from ideas that say the moon 
does not exist when noone is looking at it.
There is also the point that you "can also wash your dishes with dirty 
water". Meaning that you can always start at the point that everything is 
just as usual and see of it works out. If your initial assumption was 
incorrect, it'll be shown in the incorrectness of the predictions you make 
because of that. So you can actually test your assumptions.
Additionally, one can always speculate about everything. But in science a 
claim without any evidence can be dismissed without any evidence. In this 
case it would mean that unless you have any evidence that the physics 
beyond our horizon are different to the one that seems to be exaclty the 
same thoughout all of our horizon then there is no evidence in favor of a 
speculation like that.
comments.author: Schmidt975

comments.text:
+Schmidt975 Thanks for taking the time to answer my questions.  
Unfortunately, I have to say that logically-speaking the answers you gave 
are not satisfactory.  There is definitely some rationale behind what 
you're saying, but it is not logically sound.  We have no way of knowing 
what is beyond the observable horizon.  It is not actually safe to assume 
anything (nor is it unsafe).  And experiments do not clearly enough show 
symmetry or lack thereof.  They show a tendency toward symmetry and do 
cosmological observations show a little consistency, but truthfully, we're 
finding out new discoveries about space and physics every day.  So, I would 
hold off on making such grand assumptions, at least for now.  Just my 
opinion, but I think it is based upon more sound logic.
comments.author: Tletna

comments.text:
That are truely some excellent questions!  I'll try to give an answer.

For the first one: the universe, on a large scale, looks like it is 
isotropic and homogeneous (meaning it looks about the same in every 
direction and from every point of view). So it looks like we are on no 
special place in the universe. Because of this, it is save to assume that 
the universe beyond our horizon is similar to the stuff we observe inside 
of it. Additionally, one would have to come up with a process, that would 
create a preference for matter in our universe and, at the same time, a 
preference for matter somewhere else. So one would have to not only answer 
why we see more matter than antimatter here but also would have to test a 
process that only could be happening outside our cosmological horizon.
Ok, you might say: what if neither of these processes were taking place and 
matter and antimatter just happened to sit at different places after the 
beginning of the universe. The problem here is: if that simply way the 
case, then the chances of finding a whole visible universe without any 
large amounts of antimatter are extremely small. One would expect at least 
some areas filled with antimatter if the physics of today are a good 
approximation to what is going on in nature.

For the second one: the best way to explain the asymmetry of matter and 
antimatter is precisely that idea! In modern particle physics people are 
looking for such a process that favours the creation of matter over the 
creation of antimatter. But the search is very had, since it has been 
calculated that a extremely tiny difference between how matter and 
antimatter interact would allow a universe full of matter.

I hope that was a little helpful :)
